This is only true for home solutions, which is more politically sensitive. For utility level solar, solar farms are proving themselves as reliable and extremely low upkeep cost at the same time as manufacturing them is getting incredibly cheap. Global installed solar capacity has been growing literally exponentially, doubling every 3 years. The more panels that are manufactured, the more economies of scale kick in, and it becomes even cheaper to make, making even not so sunny places cost effective for solar, even in the absence of sufficient grid level storage mechanisms. Which are also developing fast, just not exponentially like solar. In 10 years, solar will be the largest source of electrical power on the planet. Energy produced by them will cost less than half as much as the cheapest electricity to produce today. No politician can deny reality in the long term, as republicans are finding out as people whose homes are destroyed by flooding in the SE US are more likely to believe in climate change regardless of political leaning. Solar is going to be a huge part of the future, and most people dont see it yet. Of course having said this, many of the factors I just named mean that actual margins in the industry will probably go pretty low in the long term, and its going to be essentially impossible to establish a moat. So still hard to pick individual winners.

" As of June 2024, three small modular reactors (SMRs) are operational:
HTR-PM: A 210 MW high-temperature gas-cooled modular pebble bed reactor in China
KLT-40S: A 70 MW reactor in Russia used in the Akademik Lomonosov floating nuclear power plant
HTR-10: A 2.5 MW reactor in China "
furthermore here is the balance of the story with respect to SMR's
" There are over 80 SMR designs and concepts in development around the world.
The US leads in announced SMR projects, with nearly 4 GW.

ARRY has the highest Piotroski Score in the sector - a Score of 7

 ( fwiw, NVDA has a Score of 6) 

The Piotroski Score was devised by Professor of Accounting at Stanford, Joseph D. Piotroski.

For every criteria below met, a stock is awarded one point. The points are then added up to determine the value of the stock, with Nine being the highest and Zero being the lowest.

Positive Net Income
Positive return on assets in the current year
Positive operating cash flow in the current year
Cash flow from operations being greater than net Income
Lower ratio of long term debt in the current period, compared to the previous year
Higher current ratio this year compared to the previous year
No new shares were issued in the last year
A higher gross margin compared to the previous year
A higher asset turnover ratio compared to the previous year


This stuff matters the most at the end of the day.

AI Overview



+1
The Piotroski score can be unreliable because it doesn't consider many factors that are important for understanding a company's financial health: 
 
Doesn't consider management
The Piotroski score doesn't consider the quality of management or how financial ratios have changed over time. 
 
Doesn't consider macroeconomics
The Piotroski score doesn't consider macroeconomics, competition, or technological developments. 
 
Doesn't consider growth
The Piotroski score doesn't consider growth, which is important for long-term shareholders. 
 
Only considers recent data
The Piotroski score compares a company's performance to the previous year's data, which can be unreliable. 
 
Can be affected by unusual events
The Piotroski score can be unreliable during unusual events, like the pandemic, which can affect the markets. 
 
Can be misleading for micro-cap stocks
The Piotroski score might not be useful for micro-cap stocks, which can lack liquidity and have negative or low returns. 
 
Can be misleading for capital-intensive companies
Capital-intensive companies that need to take on a lot of debt to be efficient might get low Piotroski scores.
